Description: Indie bands & DJs rock crowds in a small, funky space that also offers food & lounge areas.
Attributes: Best nights on Thursday, Friday, Saturday

Came here for a concert and was able to get right at the front of the stage. You can either stand in the lower area or stand\/ sit in the upper area--the lower area goes very far back so don't arrive too late otherwise you will be far from the stage. The lower area has a bar, where they have beers on tap and they also had a cocktail special named after one of the performer's songs. They also have an upper area which is a decent size--the regulars seem to go straight up there and grab a seat on the couches and chairs. The seats are good if you don't want to be down below where you will be tight standing next to people.I like that a Rickshaw Shop is walking distance from Civic Center bart! Maybe a 10 min walk. This place has a divey and gurngy vibe, and I wouldn't want it any other way."},{"VenueName":"Rickshaw Stop","ReviewDate":1573344000000,"ReviewContent":"A smaller venue that doesn't feel claustrophobic. We came by when doors opened for Emo Nite but we were told that they weren't quite ready and to circle back later.When we did come back, there was a small line but it moved by pretty quickly. Once in we were stamped to indicate that our tickets were checked and we had wristbands placed on us for being 21+. Once you're inside you can pretty much see to the end of the venue with the main stage at the back. To the right as you walk in are the restrooms and there is a bar on this floor as well. There are a set of stairs to the left and there was a sign indicating that there was a bar upstairs that was open and that coat check was also located up there.When we got up there the bar was definitely not functional. There was a rack where you could hang up your jackets and take a ticket but there were no staff monitoring that so someone could in theory take your jacket. The upstairs area has some couches and has a lower level where you can watch from upstairs.I didn't drink that night but they did have a spout with water to the left of the main bar so you could help yourself.All in all it was a pretty intimate venue. The event didn't seem too packed so maybe that's why there was still a decent amount of room to move around. I think some of the hiccups may have had to do with the event organizers rather than the venue."},{"VenueName":"Rickshaw Stop","ReviewDate":1568678400000,"ReviewContent":"The grungier the better! PARKING: we were able to get street parking on franklin very easily-and bc it was so late we didn't have to pay! Mahalia and Kiah both put on great sets, and it so cool to see them in such an intimate setting. I would come back to Rickshaw again. *one thing I will note is that if you're a person that has any type of issue w\/ smoke or asthma or just breathing, a lot of people were smoking\/vaping. and in such a small space, it was kind of heavy-so that wasn't too fun."},{"VenueName":"Rickshaw Stop","ReviewDate":1533686400000,"ReviewContent":"I saw a sold out The Hold Steady show here.  Bad experience.  I've been to 100+ venues around the country, and I've never been so crammed into a tiny club that to watch the show I had to stand in the back of the club, literally 5 feet from the bar's center, directly under bar lights shining down on me.  Talk about a terrible way to see a show.  All lit up, constantly bothered by people trying to maneuver to buy a drink, and with all the bar noise.  There was no way to move forward--the place was that inappropriately packed.  Also, the temperature inside was too warm -- running one large fan in the balcony area doesn't cut it, people -- and the small balcony has some stupid garage door-type thing pulled partially down that blocks much of the view of the stage from the balcony.  Awful, like nobody gives a sh!t who works there.On top of the issues I mention above, the staff lack common sense.  After showing my ID, they stamped a VERY large \"HOT\" stamp on the inside of my right wrist.  It took me 1.5 days to scrub this off of my skin, and it looked far more like a \"HOT\" tattoo than a club stamp.  Thanks, guys--how about using some discretion in your stamp selection.I ended up leaving the show after about six songs despite being a big fan of the band, as I just didn't feel like dealing with the nonsense.  The show two nights earlier at GAMH was night-and-day more fun to attend.  The Rickshaw Stop may be a decent place to see an unpopular, uncrowded show, but I will never return for a show that I feel might be sold out."},{"VenueName":"Rickshaw Stop","ReviewDate":1532390400000,"ReviewContent":"Went here last night for a concert. A hip yet unpretentious, dive-esque bar packed with a lot of character sets the stage for 3 'talks' roughly 20 minute each  about interesting and exciting topics. Talks- they are funny, they have character, they are animated speakers giving a run down of their respective field with purpose. This night we got the history of SF's Trans culture, 20 math mysteries with graphics and dancing in 20 minutes, and how a physicist is working to understand dark matter. Each was beyond entertaining, captivating, and educational without feeling talked down to or watering down the content to much. And you walking away learning some really cool stuff.This happens the 3rd Wednesday of each month and this was the 92 hosting. Great date night, or solo event, don't bring a crew this thing fills up. Get there real early if you want to have a chair or a couch space, otherwise we did the floor up front and it was pretty nice. My friend left his ticket in our Uber on the way over, so we spent the first half of the show outside trying to get that back. By the time we made it inside, we were only able to catch the last two songs. On our way out, I found myself venting to guy by the door about what had happened and how I was disappointed we missed the majority of the show. Turned out, he was the owner, and asked me and my friend to come over. He pulled out wristbands for us to attend the 10 o clock show, and told us to have a good night. Lots of parking lots with reasonable rates nearby."},{"VenueName":"Rickshaw Stop","ReviewDate":1484956800000,"ReviewContent":"I can't say that I'm still a fan of the Rickshaw Stop. I like the small intimate size. And I like that the restrooms are by the door and there's hardly ever a wait. Drinks are pretty cheap and I like that the water is self-service at the end of the bar.\u00a0But the shows start late and go really long. The doors don't open until 8 o'clock, and the first act doesn't usually go on until 8:45. And don't expect the main act until well after 10. At the last show, there was a half hour wait between the two. The place was full, the stage was set, and everyone was antsy and ready to go. Is it a ploy to sell more drinks? It might not bother me if it a was the weekend but on a weeknight when I still need to take public transportation home and get up at 6:30 the next morning to go back to work, I'd like to wrap up at a reasonable hour. Subsequently. every time I've been here, I've had to leave before the main act was over which sucks. Another thing is that sound system isn't very good. I didn't realize how bad until I saw a couple of shows at The Independent for a few dollars more on the ticket price. I could hear every word the singers were singing. At the Rickshaw, the bass is really low and throbbing sometimes to the point of ridiculousness. Even in the intimate moments of songs, when the artist is playing the keyboard and singing, the sound is muddy and distorted. Not OK! They do have a balcony with a few seats but they'll be taken early by people who know they're in it for a long haul."},{"VenueName":"Rickshaw Stop","ReviewDate":1482624000000,"ReviewContent":"I saw Mako here. I can't complain much -- it was a small, intimate venue with hipster vibes, which I really liked. You get a great view of whoever's performing no matter where you are on the floor. The crowd, thankfully, isn't too unruly. The tickets were also very, very cheap - $36 for two tickets after taxes\/fees and everything!I only have a few minor complaints. The sound system could have been better -- when a violinist was playing, I could barely hear that part, which was sad, because the violinist is a big part of the song. Though I'm not sure how much of that is the performer's fault vs. the venue's fault.The ticket also said 8pm, but Mako didn't start playing until much later -- probably around 10. I was a little annoyed at the time, as I didn't know how much time I was allotted to skip the opening act to finish up a task I needed to do. I'd have liked a little more transparency in terms of when the acts started\/finished.But those are only minor issues. Can't wait to come back again for the next show!"},{"VenueName":"Rickshaw Stop","ReviewDate":1472169600000,"ReviewContent":"This place always seems to have the best upcoming indie acts. Bigger venues like The Fillmore and Bill Graham might have some of the bigger names, but whenever I discover a really great new indie band and see they're playing in SF, it seems like almost every time they're playing at rickshaw. I go to a concert at least once a week, and over half of them have been at Rickshaw, and it's not like I try to go there I just kind of end up there after looking for shows I'll like. It's a small, intimate venue, and much more relaxed than places like the fillmore. I've seen people standing on benches and even sitting on the piano (down on the floor, not the stage) and no one seemed to mind. This could be handy if you're short, especially since it's a fairly low stage so if you're shorter it can be a little harder to see (it's not too bad for the short folks out there though, in addition to standing on the furniture you can pretty much show up 10 minutes before the music starts and secure a spot in the front, or go off to the side if you don't mind the awkward angle but still want to see).The sound system sounds great, though I'm not audiophile so I cant really say much about the quality other than it seems perfectly fine. I can say though that they've probably got the best lighting system of any similarly sized venue in town, and they've just put in four brand new high tech led spotlights that look fantastic, and this is in addition to what was already a really nice looking set. Once the music starts it looks absolutely gorgeous on stage, and unfortunately your phone camera will never do it justice.The shows always are listed at 8, but they always start the music 40-50 min after, it seems to be a rule that the artists wait until at least 8:40 to start. The headliner will usually start at around ten.I don't drink, so unfortunately can't tell you much about the drink quality or pricing. They do always have a drink themed on the band that'll be playing, so it's kinda fun to see what kind of drink related puns they come up with.My biggest complaint is the lack of box office hours, you can only buy the tickets online or at the door of the specific show (can't buy tickets for a different show). I've heard you can buy the tickets for there at the independent and some other places, but I've never tried it. Also it's cash only, which is kind of annoying. But hey, buying the ticket is always the worst part of a concert right?This is a great venue, very conveniently placed (right smack in the middle of town and two blocks away from bart\/muni underground), cheap tickets (usually around $14 at the door), great sound and lighting, and most important of all always having the best acts, I plan on returning often"},{"VenueName":"Rickshaw Stop","ReviewDate":1470960000000,"ReviewContent":"This place is the best. All in all five stars"},{"VenueName":"Rickshaw Stop","ReviewDate":1469318400000,"ReviewContent":"Came here to see The Drums and it was a perfect size for an obscure show like this. Nerd Nite should be in an office space, church, library...anywhere with enough space for people to sit."},{"VenueName":"Rickshaw Stop","ReviewDate":1458086400000,"ReviewContent":"I attended a concert here. It is not a big venue although still lots of space to dance and it does not feel like cramped quarters. We had a major issue with the air conditioning that made it pretty bad after the first three songs. They fixed it mid concert but the downstairs back area never got any better, closer to the stage was ok."},{"VenueName":"Rickshaw Stop","ReviewDate":1455667200000,"ReviewContent":"For Nerd NiteKey tips- Buy tickets ahead of time (as in a week ahead of time). They do sell out. They sell 30 tickets at the door but even when buckets of rain were falling from the sky there was a line of people who had been waiting 30+ minutes for these standby tickets.- Line up ~6:30p if you want seats and a clear view- Come with an open mindThe venue was easy to find by Van Ness and Fell. Plus there will likely be a long line forming anyway. The location itself lacked seating leaving many on the floor and uncertainty whether there was a clear escape route (say if I needed to visit the ladies room). Thankfully people at the floor sat down and my view from a chair was perfect. They serve food and drink if you are hungry but I personally didn't feel like throwing $8 for a grilled cheese. As for nerd nite itself, I appreciate that there were 3 different topics; however it really is a hit or miss. It is best to buy a ticket if you have interest in at least one of the topics because otherwise these are volunteer lecturers and not professional speakers."},{"VenueName":"Rickshaw Stop","ReviewDate":1453593600000,"ReviewContent":"There's no doubt about it, the Rickshaw has been my favorite venue since I was in high school. Not too far from Civic Center of you don't mind trudging through the  Burger King favela, you'll find yourself at this oasis on Fell, a place with cheap drinks ($10 card minimum guys, sorry!) and the best artists, be they well-known or relatively unknown. The place has one charming quality that I can't seem to find anywhere else-- intimacy. To come as close as you can to your favorite artists, completely in their element, there's something raw and authentic. Someone will miss a note or botch a cord and nobody feels shy about it, artists feel a certain openness here that is unfound anywhere else I've been. When I see a show here, it's always a chill crowd and an honest, interactive experience. And at be end of the night, I stumble through the homeless encampment with my stolen band poster (sorry again Rickshaw!) and grab some chicken fries before I hop on BART.   The to-go spot."},{"VenueName":"Rickshaw Stop","ReviewDate":1452988800000,"ReviewContent":"Rickshaw Stop is such an intimate venue. It's VERY small. I've been here twice now for two different shows -- one was for a sold out show (Oh Wonder). The merch table is usually set up by the front door, near the restrooms. There's a bar downstairs. $20 minimum on cards. A beer & a jack & coke was ~$14. The stage is set up downstairs and it's literally the smallest stage I've ever seen. There definitely isn't very much room on the stage, but the dancefloor is decent sized. It makes the shows very intimate since you can get right up close and personal with your favorite artists. There is also an upstairs balcony area, which is nice when you go to the really packed shows. If you're short like me, it's fantastic being up there because then you can still see LOL. Sound quality is pretty great, since the venue is so small ya know, it's not too hard to see\/hear everything very well. What else is there to say? Great bar\/venue to see some of your favorite artists in a super intimate setting. I would definitely recommend checking out a show here if you get the chance!"},{"VenueName":"Rickshaw Stop","ReviewDate":1452902400000,"ReviewContent":"It's a nice small venue. I didn't get a chance to check it out, but there are seats up there (ground floor is standing room only). The people working there were nice, and I'd probably go back if there's ever an artist I like performing there."},{"VenueName":"Rickshaw Stop","ReviewDate":1450828800000,"ReviewContent":"Cool little spot to see a show.  Good prices on booze and easy to get drinks.  Only downside is the artists go on very late. We showed up around 10 or 10:30pm here to see Reptar and the opening act had just started playing.  Good thing we were not planning on taking the Caltrain back to Palo Alto - Reptar didn't go on until after 11:30pm."},{"VenueName":"Rickshaw Stop","ReviewDate":1450137600000,"ReviewContent":"RE: Party venueThis venue was recommended to me through a colleague and as soon as we visited the space, we were sold. Thanks to Dan, Harp, and their team, we had the best corporate holiday party our staff has ever had! Dan was incredible to work with and made sure we got a great deal. He was easy-going, helpful, and genuinely excited about the event which made planning so much more enjoyable. They made setup and cleanup a breeze, allowed us to move things around to fit our party's needs, and even helped decorate with the holiday vibe we were going for. You could tell everyone wanted to help us have a good time and keep things running smoothly. The drinks were good (they let us have 2 custom drinks on the menu which was fun and popular among guests), the bar service was fast and easy (we used the drink ticket approach), and Dan was fast and easy to communicate with throughout the entire process. Parking and safety were non-issues, there was plenty of space for our 150+ guests, and again the vibe the space lends itself to is just right for a trendy mingling and festive atmosphere.If you're looking for a hip, cool place to throw a party, this is it! Seriously, give them a call."},{"VenueName":"Rickshaw Stop","ReviewDate":1450137600000,"ReviewContent":"I loved the vibe, I loved the band, I loved the venue.....except for THE SOUND. It was so loud that you could not distinguish one guitar from the other...the bass was this huge thumping drone, and forget about understanding any lyrics. At one point (on 12\/14\/15) Murray Lightburn from the Dears was onstage with just an acoustic guitar doing a beautiful song with quiet dynamics, and it was still so loud that everyone kept their earplugs in. It's just ridiculous. In an intimate atmosphere you should be able to hear EVERYTHING. I actually went up to the guy at the booth in between bands and politely said it was too loud. He just shrugged. The same deal at the Bottom of the Hill...volume to the point of mandatory earplugs and total quality distortion. Disappointing....because the venue is great otherwise."},{"VenueName":"Rickshaw Stop","ReviewDate":1449964800000,"ReviewContent":"If a new band books a gig at Rickshaw, you can bet they're going to start making it big in due time (Ellie Goulding, Lily Allen, Bastille, Sam Smith, The Wombats, etc.) Overall, i love this venue and the hidden crazy gem that it is. Rickshaw is small enough so that if you get there early, you can literally be inches away from the performers, but it's also large enough so that you can get down and groovy upstairs and in the back. However, it does get insanely packed, so be warned if you're going to a sold out show. If a show is sold out and you are kicking yourself in the butt for not getting tickets in time, have no fear! They usually sell a limited number of tickets at the door, so get there early if you want to score tickets. There is also an open dance floor after the gig is over, which is always fun. The performances are always fantastic and if you're from the bay, I highly recommend seeing a show during your time here. It's definitely a bucket list venue for the avid concertgoer."},{"VenueName":"Rickshaw Stop","ReviewDate":1446768000000,"ReviewContent":"You're an idiot if you rated Rickshaw 3 stars or less.  This small, cozy venue is pulling in some serious talent.  The tickets are cheap, the drinks are strong and cheap, and staff is attentive.  What's not to like? Idiots."},{"VenueName":"Rickshaw Stop","ReviewDate":1446595200000,"ReviewContent":"I've been here multiple times and every time I go the bouncers are assholes.
